PROE BROOKLLYN TO NEw YORE --S TODAY A D YESTERDAY

730691f-a.text:

730663f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730663f-a.text:
A general view westward from the Brookl,n Bridge (under construction),
over the Cherry Hill section, Printing House Square, City Hall Commons and
westward to the Hudson (North) River. Shown in the foreground, is the
Manhattan abutment of the bridge, with the Roosevelt Street Ferry to Broad-
way, Brooklyn adjoining. Points of interest shown are, U.S. Post Office,
Tribune Building, Harper's and the Newsboy's Home.
About 1870-1875.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
Published in the American on December 1906, and the New York Times
of October 20, 1912.

masted schooners in the foreground on the South Street waterfront.
About 1880.

730665f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730665f-a.text:
The Brooklyn Bridge under construotion, with the ''Catwalk'' and Manhattan
anchorage in the foreground. Also shown is a general view westward over
the City Hall and Printing House Souare area, to the Hudson River, with its
Jersey shore line just beyond. Note how the U.S. Post Office and the Tri-
bune Buildings predominated at this date.
About 1878-1879.
Ewing Galloway.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

730704f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [looking towards lower Manhattan from Brooklyn].
730704f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge: The financial district of lower Manhattan as viewed
in a southwestward direction from Brooklyn and under the Brooklyn Bridge.
The prominent building shown is the 70-storied structure of the Bank of
Manhattan Company.
About 1928.
Ewing Galloway.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(Not a dry mount item).

730717f-c.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge.
730717f-c.text:
(1).  Brooklyn Bridge (suspension); beginning at Centre Street and
Park Row, facing City Hall Park, in Manhattan, and terminating in
Brooklyn at Fulton and MSands Streets. Actual work was begun in
January, 1870 and it was completed in May, 1884, having been open-
ed in the previous year. Its overall length is 1; miles, width
85 feet, with a central snan across the East River, 1595 feet
long and 135 feet above high water mark. John A. Roebling, who
drew urthe snecifications an d bepan construction was succeeded upon
his death by his son, Washington A. 'oebling. Being the first
bridge to connect Manhattan and Brooklyn, it acquired a colorful
history and world-wide fame as a wonder of modern engineering and
human endeavor. ( see: Moses King, Handbook of New York Cit (1892).)
June 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

730681f.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [Manhattan - East River - Brooklyn.]
730681f.text:
Brooklyn Bridge: A general view southward from same. Downtown
Manhattan is on the right; Bedloes Island and its Statue of Liberty
in the center and Governors Island (with its rotund ''Castle William')
to the left. In the foreground is a ferry boat preparing to dock
at the ferry house at the foot of Fulton Street, rooklyn.
1894
J. S. Johnston, photo
Copyright 1894
Ewing Galloway
NO REPRODUCTIONS

730699f-a.text:

the East River, and viewing eastward to Brooklyn. Note the painters giving
the Brooklyn Bridge its annual protecting coat.
About 1925.
Ewing Galloway.

730731f-b.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - Manhattan approach.
730731f-b.text:
The Brooklyn Bridge and it's Manhattan approach as
viewed eastward from the Municipal Building. This
crosses the East River to the Brooklyn locale betw-
een the Columbia Heights area (right) and Flatbush
Awenue Extension (left, approach to the Manhattan
Bridge). The foreground zone has at times been
known as the ''Swamp' and''Cherry Hill'.
April 1940
George D. Chinn

730674f-a.title: Bridges - Brooklyn Bridge - [A westward view towards Manhattan.]
730674f-a.text:
Brooklyn Bridge: A westward view towards Manhattan .
This enlargement from an original lantern slide has
been reversed in the printing. The shot tower at the
right should be on the left. The domed structure in
the background is the Pulitzer (World) Bldg.
Date 7
